chapter: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.explanation: Inspiratory stridor is typically associated with supraglottic lesions.
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: What is the most common cause of congenital stridor?
questions.explanation: Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor.It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in duringinspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in theprone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shapedepiglottis is seen.535

questions.question: What is congenital laryngeal stridor also known as?
questions.explanation: Laryngomalacia is also called congenital laryngeal stridor. It is the most common cause of stridorin newborns.

questions.question: A 1-week-old infant has been diagnosed with laryngomalacia. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

options.A: Most common cause of stridor in newborns

questions.explanation: Laryngomalacia has an excellent prognosis. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in newborns. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, an omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.

questions.question: A worried mother brings her 2-week-old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of severe laryngomalacia include: • Difficulty feeding • Increased effort in breathing • Poor weight gain • Pauses in breathing • Frequent spitting up

questions.question: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.explanation: Myer Cotton's grading is used for subglottic stenosis. It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor, and a normal cry. Diagnosis: In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm. In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm. The Myer Cotton's grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment: Grade 1: <50% stenosis, Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis, Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis, Grade 4: No lumen detected. Other options: Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma. Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system. Option D - Modified Mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. Theswelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is agurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.explanation: On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce's sign. The givenclinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patientpresents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.question: You are the ENT resident performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and reportthe presence of a laryngocele. The given condition is due to an enlarged diverticulum fromwhich part of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngealsaccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle.537It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure.It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling inthe neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization. External laryngocele is managed by excision(external/LASER).ThyrohyoidmembraneMLaryngoceleOMARROWLaryngocele:ExternalcomponentInternalcomponent

questions.question: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth. The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve: to wait and watch, steroid therapy, tracheostomy and observation. If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include: LASER excision, laryngofissure and excision, and pexy and plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc.)

questions.question: A 30-year-old singer complains of a change in her voice. Direct laryngoscopy procedure showsthe presence of laryngeal cysts. Which part of the larynx does the cyst arise from?532
questions.explanation: Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds.538These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can causeairway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.

questions.explanation: The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depictsa laryngeal papilloma.Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPVtype 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3-5 years of age (juvenilepapillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of thelarynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation.They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy.Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years.It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same asjuvenile papillomatosis.Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish towhite grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascularcore. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. questions.question: A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratorydistress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with chronic hoarseness (3 months) of voice andrespiratory distress for 2 weeks suggests the diagnosis of respiratory papillomatosis (juvenilepapillomatosis).Croup (Option A) and acute epiglottitis (Option D), which cause acute upper respiratory tractobstruction, are ruled out due to the chronic nature of the symptoms. In croup, the upper airwayobstruction becomes apparent after 1 to 3 days of low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. Onthe other hand, in epiglottitis, a child experiences respiratory distress within hours of developinga fever.Vocal nodules (Option C) are not typically associated with respiratory distress.Respiratory papillomatosis is the most common respiratory tract neoplasm in children. They aresimple warts (benign tumors) caused by human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 commonly seen inchildren aged 3 to 5 years.The course involves remissions and exacerbations of recurrent papillomas, mostly affecting theglottic area (vocal cords), and supraglottis. The patient presents with progressively worseninghoarseness, sleep-disordered breathing, dyspnea, stridor, and severe airway obstruction if leftuntreated.Diagnosis confirmed by direct laryngoscopy, which shows grape-like projections (shown below),and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. Antivirals likeinterferon alpha2a, ribavirin, cidofovir, and acyclovir are used as adjunct therapies.540Other options:Option A: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The patientinitially presents with an upper respiratory tract infection (rhinorrhea, pharyngitis, cough,low-grade fever) followed by a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor.Option C: Vocal nodule (singer's or screamer's nodule) occurs as a result of chronic vocal abuse.They appear symmetrically at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two third of thevocal cord. The patient presents with chronic hoarseness and voice fatigue.The image below shows symmetric vocal nodules:Option D: Acute epiglottitis is caused by streptococcus pyogenes, pneumococci, Hemophilusinfluenzae, and staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive courseof high-grade fever, dyspnea, and stridor.541
